fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: • An article headlined New homeowners: 'Falling market helped us', should have made clear, in accordance with the Guardian's editorial code, that the journalist who wrote it is related to one of the homebuyers featured (26 August, page 7). • JM Coetzee is not the only double winner of the Booker prize, as we suggested in a report on this year's shortlist: Peter Carey has also won twice (Coetzee and Waters among contenders as judges hail strength of Booker shortlist, 9 September, page 9). • A quote was misattributed due to an editing error in a report, England could win Euro 2009 tomorrow. Guess why you haven't heard about that? (9 September, page 3). England football coach Hope Powell, not Ian Watmore, the FA's chief executive, made the remarks that began "It's hard work, I've been doing it for 11 years and I'm always trying to push the game." • In the Tech Media Invest 100 supplement the work of the company MirriAd should have been described as "complete solutions for embedded advertising in video", not online marketing campaign mangement (The top 100 tech media companies, 7 September, page 2). • We were wrong to say that Microsoft's Xbox 360 uses the 45 nanometer processor; the latest version uses the older 65nm technology (Tough game ahead as Sony slims down its PS3, 27 August, page 5, Technology). The same article said Sony claims its new PlayStation 3 Slim, using a 45nm processor, consumes 11% less power than the previous version of PS3 – the claim is 34% less. It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning +44 (0)20 3353 4736 between 11am and 5pm UK time Monday to Friday excluding public holidays. Send mail to The Readers' Editor, Kings Place, 90 York Way, London N1 9GU. Email: reader@theguardian.com
